title: Which country got the greatest benefit from the Acts of Union 1707, England or Scotland? - Quora

response.answer_text: As a country, England. It was after all an English idea, intended to solve English problems. As individuals, Scotsmen, since they could now exploit new trade and employment opportunities south of the border. The British Empire was built by Scottish governors and Irish soldiers. Slavery, which was now becoming uneconomic was first challenged by Lord Mansfield, a Scot who had somehow got himself appointed Lord Chief Justice of England [sic] and cut the Gordian knot of the legal position of slaves in England by declaring that it was not necessary to contemplate the abolition of slavery, simply because it had never legally existed in the first place: a piece of legal sophistry that only one trained in Scots (Roman) law could have thought of. From the 19th century, more Scotsmen, Irishmen and the like (even a Welshman, a half American and a Canadian) have made it to 10 Downing Street, than have Englishmen (not forgetting the two who were not men at all)! At a lower level, my father who spent his life in the building trade reported never having met a site foreman who was not Scottish.

The Act of Union, effected through cash bribery of Scottish peers and the promise of representation in the House of Lords, gave Scotland customs union with a burgeoning UK global economy and a consequent improvement, over time, of trade and prosperity. (Scottish agriculture was also improved by importing “scientific” agricultural techniques from England.) Significantly, there was lukewarm Scottish support for the 1715 and 1745 Jacobite uprisings, and by the 1760s the intellectual and economic flowering of the Scottish Enlightenment was in full swing, while the vigorous Scottish education system**, especially at further education level, produceed generations of engineers and chemists who played key roles in the Industrial Revolution and the development of manufacturing in Scotland. **established by the 1633 Education Act passed by the Parliament of Scotland (see Education Act 1633 - Wikipedia)
